I work hard at everything I do, and it is reflected in my regular raises and promotions. Unfortunately, a lot of the time, when my success is mentioned, so are my looks. You don't get to tell a person of colour what is and isn 't racist when you're white, because you cannot fully view the experience from their point of view. You are not the one living with the oppression; they are. Has someone ever said about you, "Chris is a highly skilled, super valuable employee, with a rockin' hot body"? Or how about, "Yeah Chris, it's very interesting that you excel at x, y and z. And I mean, you're so hot too! Beauty and brains!"? Or "Man, your ass sure looks nice in those slacks. You're working this promotion!"? What about, "It's a good thing you're hot, because otherwise you would've had a really hard time landing that job/raise/promotion."? Because I and almost ev ery woman I know has heard things a lot like this in their field. Those are not compliments. These are inappropriate for the topic of discussion, and demeaning to me as a person. Because while I have the good self-esteem to know that I am awesome, my looks are not equal to the value of my hard work and dedication to my education and career.   Imagine having what I just described as your entire life, day in and day out. I have never had a single man I have discussed the subject of work with talk about anyone treating them like this. Sure some guys have that one girl who hits on them a lot, and makes them horribly uncomfortable. It's equally uncalled for, and while that is harassment, it's not quite the same thing. Because that is harassment, not bla tant sexism. It happens because the harasser is an awful person, not because the victim is male. This specific kind of commenting is not only uncalled for, but also revolves around the fact that it is a woman being discussed, and therefore she must be critiqued by her outer appearance. I know it seems like a harmless compliment when you're not the one on the receiving end, but when it is the constant, overarching narrative of womens' lives, there is a very serious problem. And these things I have mentioned are the most blatant, easy to decry, casually sexist actions. As are some of the instances in this video, because they are blatant. Most of the aggression is subtle though, and hard to navigate for people who haven't really been there. As a woman, this shit makes me uncomfortable, and I don't like to be treated like my looks are more important then my career/education/personality/humanity. And most women I know feel the same. We're even telling you now that it makes us feel unsafe and uncomfortable, and that it's sexist because it places value on appearance above and beyond, or equal to personal achievement.
